new_src_summary: On New Year's Eve, December 31, 1999, the author, then 12 years old, attended a church service at a Texas church with old wooden pews, an organ, a choir, and a baptism pool. The atmosphere was tense with anticipation, hope for salvation, and a sense of impending doom, as the congregation believed this night to be the Second Coming of Christ and the end of the world. The author, having reached the "age of accountability," felt a sense of urgency to prepare for the end times, attending church frequently, listening for signs of the end, and reading popular "Left Behind" novels to develop a survival strategy. The pastor led the congregation to the altar for prayer as midnight approached, with different groups occupying specific positions. The author humorously refers to the deacons and their wives as the "Baptist Bourgeoisie," highlighting the social hierarchy within the congregation. During the service, the elderly members of the congregation, who had endured hardship throughout their lives, were the focus of attention. The author notes their deep faith and hope for salvation, likening it to their medieval predecessors' anticipation of the end of the world and his grandmother's eagerness to watch the Oprah Winfrey Show. As the prayers intensified, the author held onto his grandmother's hand, hoping to join her in heaven. However, when the event concluded past midnight, the author felt disillusioned, believing that the elders had been misled by false promises. The merged summary captures the personal narrative style, reflective and humorous tone, and serious discussion of religious beliefs, while also conveying the themes of faith, hope, and disillusionment explored in the second paragraph.
new_tgt_summary: Le 31 décembre 1999, dans une église texane, un jeune garçon de 12 ans, récemment entré dans l'âge de la responsabilité, se prépare intensément pour ce qu'il croit être le Second Avènement du Christ. Il assiste régulièrement aux offices, dévorant les livres "Laissés pour compte" et élaborant un plan pour échapper à la marque de la bête, tout en anticipant le défi à venir si l'enlèvement ne se produit pas. À 23h50, avec seulement dix minutes avant le prédit retour de Jésus, le pasteur rassemble la congrégation autour de l'autel pour une prière finale. Les groupes de la congrégation prennent leurs places traditionnelles, illustrant les hiérarchies sociales présentes même dans l'attente du Second Avènement aux États-Unis. Ils sont les véritables vedettes pour le narrateur, lui-même ayant attendu ce moment toute sa vie. Il suit sa grand-mère dans l'au-delà, tenant fermement sa main pendant la prière intense, au milieu des cris, de la musique de l'orgue et de la chaleur. new_src_summary: On New Year's Eve 1999, a 12-year-old author found themselves immersed in a tense and hopeful atmosphere at a Texas church, where the congregation, including the author, awaited what they believed would be the Second Coming of Christ and the end of the world. Amidst the old wooden pews, organ music, choir singing, and a baptism pool, the anticipation was palpable, fueled by a sense of impending doom and salvation. Having reached the "age of accountability," the author felt a pressing need to prepare for the end times through frequent church attendance, listening for signs of the end, and reading survival strategy-focused "Left Behind" novels. The pastor led the congregation in prayer as midnight approached, with different groups occupying specific positions, and the author humorously referred to the deacons and their wives as the "Baptist Bourgeoisie," illustrating the social hierarchy within the congregation. Elderly members, who had endured hardship throughout their lives, were the focus of attention due to their deep faith and hope for salvation, reminiscent of medieval predecessors' anticipation of the end times and the author's grandmother's eagerness for the Oprah Winfrey Show. As the prayers escalated, the author held onto their grandmother's hand, yearning to join her in heaven. However, when the event passed without incident, the author felt disillusioned, believing that the elders had been misled by false promises. This disillusionment marked the beginning of a journey filled with doubt and a search for meaning and understanding in life. Initially, the author had been deeply committed to their faith, praying, resisting temptation, and undergoing baptism, only to experience a profound sense of betrayal when the expected return of Jesus did not occur. This realization that belief systems could be flawed sparked a wellspring of doubt that permeated the author's previously unshakable convictions. Instead of abandoning belief entirely, the author embraced the possibility of questioning and reevaluating the nature of truth. This journey took the author through pivotal moments in life, from attending Yale University with hopes of transcending the hardships of their upbringing in Oak Cliff, Texas, to facing the harsh reality of violence during a winter break burglary. An internship at Lehman Brothers in 2008, initially promising financial security, ended in disappointment amid the financial crisis. Lastly, working in Washington D.C. during Barack Obama's campaign, which promised transformative change, also failed to provide the salvation sought after. Throughout these experiences, the author clung to hope and belief, seeking something concrete to anchor their faith in, reflecting a sense of loss and disillusionment yet marked by resilience and an ongoing quest for truth against the backdrop of significant historical events. The personal narrative style, reflective and humorous tone, and serious discussion of religious beliefs are preserved, while the themes of faith, hope, and disillusionment are explored in depth.
new_tgt_summary: Le 31 décembre 1999, dans une église texane, un jeune garçon de 12 ans, nouvellement entré dans l'âge de la responsabilité, se prépare intensément pour ce qu'il croit être le Second Avènement du Christ. Passionné par les livres "Laissés pour compte", il planifie sa fuite de la marque de la bête, tout en anticipant le défi si l'enlèvement ne se produit pas. À 23h50, le pasteur rassemble la congrégation pour une prière finale, les membres prenant leurs places traditionnelles, illustrant les hiérarchies sociales présentes même dans l'attente du Second Avènement. Le narrateur, qui a attendu ce moment toute sa vie, suit sa grand-mère dans l'au-delà, tenant fermement sa main pendant la prière intense. Cependant, après le "Amen", malgré l'absence du Sauveur tant attendu, il reste émerveillé par la foi inébranlable des anciens croyants, reconnaissant d'avoir suivi leur exemple. Cet événement marque le début d'une crise de foi pour l'auteur, qui, malgré ses croyances initialement solides, commence à douter après diverses expériences de vie, dont son entrée à Yale, une agression armée durant une pause hivernale et l'effondrement de Lehman Brothers où il travaillait. Ces expériences l'amènent à réaliser que ni l'éducation, ni le travail, ni l'espérance politique ne garantissent le salut ou la sécurité.

new_src_summary:
On New Year's Eve 1999, a 12-year-old author stood amidst the tense and hopeful atmosphere of a Texas church, awaiting what they believed would be the Second Coming of Christ. Surrounded by the old wooden pews, organ music, choir singing, and a baptism pool, the anticipation was palpable, fueled by a sense of impending doom and salvation. The author, having reached the "age of accountability," felt a pressing need to prepare for the end times through frequent church attendance, listening for signs of the end, and reading survival strategy-focused "Left Behind" novels. The pastor led the congregation in prayer as midnight approached, with different groups occupying specific positions. Elderly members, who had endured hardship throughout their lives, were the focus of attention due to their deep faith and hope for salvation. As the prayers escalated, the author held onto their grandmother's hand, yearning to join her in heaven. However, when the event passed without incident, the author felt disillusioned, believing that the elders had been misled by false promises. This disillusionment marked the beginning of a journey filled with doubt and a search for meaning and understanding in life.

Initially, the author had been deeply committed to their faith, praying, resisting temptation, and undergoing baptism, only to experience a profound sense of betrayal when the expected return of Jesus did not occur. This realization that belief systems could be flawed sparked a wellspring of doubt that permeated the author's previously unshakable convictions. Instead of abandoning belief entirely, the author embraced the possibility of questioning and reevaluating the nature of truth. This journey took the author through pivotal moments in life, from attending Yale University with hopes of transcending the hardships of their upbringing in Oak Cliff, Texas, to facing the harsh reality of violence during a winter break burglary. An internship at Lehman Brothers in 2008, initially promising financial security, ended in disappointment amid the financial crisis. Lastly, working in Washington D.C. during Barack Obama's campaign, which promised transformative change, also failed to provide the salvation sought after. Throughout these experiences, the author clung to hope and belief, seeking something concrete to anchor their faith in, reflecting a sense of loss and disillusionment yet marked by resilience and an ongoing quest for truth against the backdrop of significant historical events.

In pursuit of meaning and purpose beyond religious beliefs, the author found themselves disillusioned with the American Dream and traditional markers of success, such as wealth and power. Inspired by Jack Kerouac's spirit of adventure, the author embarked on a journey of self-discovery, leading them to Harvard Business School where they questioned conventional wisdom and sought a deeper understanding of life's purpose. A transformative road trip across America with three friends exposed them to individuals building small businesses centered around purpose rather than profit, culminating in the creation of a nonprofit organization called MBAs Across America. This organization aimed to support socially conscious entrepreneurs and address the hunger for meaning among their generation.

However, the author's zeal for spreading this message eventually led them to a reevaluation of their beliefs and the direction of their evangelism. At a gala celebrating the achievements of Harvard Business School alumni, held under a whale replica at the Museum of Natural History in New York City, the author was surrounded by influential figures, prompting a shift in perspective and a new gospel to share. The journey from religious disillusionment to a search for meaning in life and social entrepreneurship reflects a personal narrative style, with a reflective and humorous tone, exploring themes of faith, hope, disillusionment, and resilience against the backdrop of significant historical events. The domain spans religious beliefs, personal development, and social entrepreneurship, with undertones of disillusionment with mainstream societal values. The tone shifts from despair and disillusionment to hope and purpose, ultimately ending with a hint of ambiguity and a suggestion of further transformation.
new_tgt_summary: Le 31 décembre 1999, dans une église texane, un jeune garçon de 12 ans, fortement influencé par les livres "Laissés pour compte", s'attend avec une grande anticipation au Second Avènement du Christ, prêt à fuir la marque de la bête. La tension culmine à 23h50 lorsque le pasteur mène une prière finale, mettant en évidence les structures hiérarchiques existantes même dans l'espoir du retour du Christ. Le narrateur, tenant fermement la main de sa grand-mère, partage cet instant intense avec elle. Après le "Amen", bien que le Sauveur n'apparaisse pas, l'émerveillement de l'auteur pour la foi inébranlable des plus âgés persiste, marquant le début d'une crise de foi personnelle. Celle-ci s'intensifie avec l'entrée à Yale, une agression armée durant une pause hivernale et l'effondrement de Lehman Brothers où il travaille, le conduisant à remettre en question la garantie de salut offerte par l'éducation, le travail et l'espérance politique. Face à ces défis, il poursuit sa quête de sens à l'École de commerce de Harvard, mais demeure sceptique. Un road trip imprévu avec trois amis à travers les États-Unis, totalisant 8 000 miles, conduit à la création d'une organisation à but non lucratif, MBAs Across America, après avoir collaboré avec des entrepreneurs locaux engagés. Cette initiative, répondant à la recherche de sens de leur génération, soutient des entrepreneurs nationaux. Cependant, lors d'un événement à l'École de commerce de Harvard, sous une réplique de baleine entouré de leaders contemporains, l'auteur est amené à revoir son propre évangile.

new_src_summary:
On New Year's Eve 1999, a 12-year-old author stood amidst the tense and hopeful atmosphere of a Texas church, awaiting what they believed would be the Second Coming of Christ. Surrounded by the old wooden pews, organ music, choir singing, and a baptism pool, the anticipation was palpable, fueled by a sense of impending doom and salvation. Initially deeply committed to their faith, the author's belief system was shaken when the expected return of Jesus did not occur, sparking a wellspring of doubt that permeated their previously unshakable convictions. This disillusionment marked the beginning of a journey filled with doubt and a search for meaning and understanding in life, leading the author through pivotal moments in life, from attending Yale University to facing the harsh reality of violence during a winter break burglary, an internship at Lehman Brothers in 2008, and working in Washington D.C. during Barack Obama's campaign. In pursuit of meaning and purpose beyond religious beliefs, the author found themselves disillusioned with the American Dream and traditional markers of success, such as wealth and power. Inspired by Jack Kerouac's spirit of adventure, the author embarked on a journey of self-discovery, leading them to Harvard Business School where they questioned conventional wisdom and sought a deeper understanding of life's purpose. A transformative road trip across America with three friends exposed them to individuals building small businesses centered around purpose rather than profit, culminating in the creation of a nonprofit organization called MBAs Across America, aiming to support socially conscious entrepreneurs and address the hunger for meaning among their generation. However, the author's zeal for spreading this message eventually led them to a reevaluation of their beliefs and the direction of their evangelism. At a gala celebrating the achievements of Harvard Business School alumni, held under a whale replica at the Museum of Natural History in New York City, the author was surrounded by influential figures, prompting a shift in perspective and a new gospel to share. 

The author then attended an event where the collective net worth of attendees surpassed half a trillion dollars, followed by a visit to an urban farm in Harlem run by a man named Tony. Tony runs a program called Harlem Grown, which provides meals and support to children living below the poverty line, many of whom are homeless. The author learns that Tony started the program with his own pension after working as a cab driver for 20 years and does not take a salary due to the program's resource struggles. The author feels a sense of shame and realization upon leaving the farm, recognizing the stark contrast between the wealth displayed at the event and the struggles faced by the children at Harlem Grown. The author realizes that they have been complicit in perpetuating a system that fails to provide structural and systemic help to communities like Harlem, Appalachia, and the Lower 9th Ward. The author reflects on their own journey, feeling duped and hoodwinked, and acknowledges the shame of being a "false savior" who has come full circle from their religious upbringing.

The merged summary explores themes of faith, hope, disillusionment, resilience, wealth disparity, social justice, and personal responsibility. The author grapples with their role in a society that often overlooks and neglects marginalized communities, leading to a sense of guilt and a desire for change. The writing style is introspective, with a reflective and humorous tone, shifting from despair and disillusionment to hope and purpose, ultimately ending with a hint of ambiguity and a suggestion of further transformation. The domain spans religious beliefs, personal development, social entrepreneurship, and wealth disparity, with undertones of disillusionment with mainstream societal values.
new_tgt_summary:
Le 31 décembre 1999, dans une église texane, un jeune garçon de 12 ans, influencé par les livres "Laissés pour compte", attendait avec anxiété le Second Avènement du Christ, prêt à fuir la marque de la bête. Sa foi était partagée avec sa grand-mère lors d'une prière finale dirigée par le pasteur à 23h50. Malgré l'absence d'apparition divine, l'émerveillement de l'auteur pour la foi indéfectible des plus âgés persiste, marquant le début d'une crise de foi personnelle. Cette crise s'accentue après son entrée à Yale, une agression armée durant une pause hivernale, et l'effondrement de Lehman Brothers où il travaillait, le poussant à remettre en question la supposée garantie de salut de l'éducation, du travail et de l'espérance politique. Suite à un voyage de 8 000 miles à travers les Etats-Unis avec trois amis, ils créent MBAs Across America, une organisation à but non lucratif, suite à leur collaboration avec des entrepreneurs locaux engagés. Cependant, malgré ce sens trouvé, un événement à l'École de commerce de Harvard amène l'auteur à revoir son évangile personnel.

Dans un revirement saisissant, l'auteur fait le pont entre une salle où la richesse totale dépasse la moitié d'un trillion de dollars et une ferme urbaine à Harlem, où les enfants vivent en dessous du seuil de pauvreté. Il rencontre Tony, un ancien chauffeur de taxi qui a créé "Harlem Grown", un programme fournissant des repas aux enfants démunis. Touché par la réalité du manque de ressources pour le programme malgré son succès, l'auteur réalise qu'il est devenu une sorte de palliatif pour un système en besoin urgent de réforme. Il comprend que son parcours personnel et son organisation ne sont que des substituts à l'aide structurelle et systémique qui ne parvient jamais dans les quartiers défavorisés. Cette prise de conscience provoque en lui une profonde tristesse et honte, se sentant trompé et exploité, comparant son rôle à celui d'un faux messie. Malgré le chemin parcouru depuis ses humbles débuts, il se retrouve, selon lui, exactement là où il avait commencé.
rel_src: But this time, the false savior was me.
Yes, I've come so far  that I'm right back where I started.
rel_tgt: Mais cette fois, le faux sauveur, c'était moi.
Oui, j'ai parcouru tant de chemin que je me retrouve exactement là où j'ai commencé.

new_src_summary:
On New Year's Eve 1999, a 12-year-old author stood amidst the tension and hope within a Texas church, awaiting the Second Coming of Christ, encapsulated by the ambiance of wooden pews, organ music, choir singing, and a baptism pool. The night's anticipation, rooted in impending doom and salvation, marked the beginning of a profound spiritual and existential journey. Initially deeply committed to their faith, the author's belief system was shaken when the expected return of Jesus did not occur, igniting a wellspring of doubt that permeated their previously unshakable convictions. This disillusionment led the author through pivotal moments in life, from attending Yale University to confronting the harsh reality of violence during a winter break burglary, interning at Lehman Brothers in 2008, and working in Washington D.C. during Barack Obama's campaign. Inspired by Jack Kerouac's spirit of adventure, the author embarked on a journey of self-discovery, questioning conventional wisdom and seeking a deeper understanding of life's purpose. A transformative road trip across America with three friends exposed them to individuals building small businesses centered around purpose rather than profit, culminating in the creation of a nonprofit organization called MBAs Across America, aiming to support socially conscious entrepreneurs and address the hunger for meaning among their generation. However, the author's zeal for spreading this message eventually led them to a reevaluation of their beliefs and the direction of their evangelism. At a gala celebrating the achievements of Harvard Business School alumni, held under a whale replica at the Museum of Natural History in New York City, the author was surrounded by influential figures, prompting a shift in perspective and a new gospel to share.

The author then attended an event where the collective net worth of attendees surpassed half a trillion dollars, followed by a visit to an urban farm in Harlem run by a man named Tony. Tony runs a program called Harlem Grown, which provides meals and support to children living below the poverty line, many of whom are homeless. The author learns that Tony started the program with his own pension after working as a cab driver for 20 years and does not take a salary due to the program's resource struggles. The author feels a sense of shame and realization upon leaving the farm, recognizing the stark contrast between the wealth displayed at the event and the struggles faced by the children at Harlem Grown. The author realizes that they have been complicit in perpetuating a system that fails to provide structural and systemic help to communities like Harlem, Appalachia, and the Lower 9th Ward. The author reflects on their own journey, feeling duped and hoodwinked, and acknowledges the shame of being a "false savior" who has come full circle from their religious upbringing.

In response to the prevailing notion that we live in an age of disbelief, the author argues that belief persists as strongly as ever, albeit in different forms, such as the teachings of motivational speakers like Brené Brown and Tony Robbins, or the doctrines espoused by publications like The New Yorker and the Harvard Business Review. The author identifies a collective desire for belief, often directed towards charismatic leaders who promise solutions to our problems, and how we revere technological progress as an infallible truth, even as we accept suffering as a consequence of capitalism. However, the author warns against the human cost of failing to question our beliefs, suggesting that such complacency can erode our foundations. Instead, they advocate for a gospel of doubt, encouraging us to consider the possibility that our current beliefs and answers might be flawed. This doubt leads the author to announce the dissolution of their own organization, MBAs Across America, and to reject the role of a savior figure. They believe that it is through doubt, rather than blind faith, that we can find hope in times of trouble and illuminate the darkness in our lives and society.

The merged summary explores themes of faith, hope, disillusionment, resilience, wealth disparity, social justice, and personal responsibility. The author grapples with their role in a society that often overlooks and neglects marginalized communities, leading to a sense of guilt and a desire for change. The writing style is introspective, rhetorical, and provocative, with a reflective and critical tone that shifts from despair and disillusionment to hope and purpose, ultimately ending with a hint of ambiguity and a suggestion of further transformation. The domain spans religious beliefs, personal development, social entrepreneurship, wealth disparity, and philosophical inquiry, with undertones of disillusionment with mainstream societal values.
new_tgt_summary:
Le 31 décembre 1999, un jeune garçon de 12 ans dans une église texane, fortement influencé par les livres "Laissés pour compte", attendait anxieusement le Second Avènement du Christ, une attente partagée avec sa grand-mère lors d'une prière finale. Malgré l'absence d'apparition divine, cet événement a marqué le début d'une crise de foi qui s'est amplifiée après son entrée à Yale, une agression armée, l'effondrement de Lehman Brothers où il travaillait, et finalement un voyage de 8 000 miles à travers les Etats-Unis. Ce voyage a conduit à la création de MBAs Across America, une organisation à but non lucratif. Toutefois, une expérience à l'École de commerce de Harvard et une rencontre avec Tony, fondateur du programme alimentaire "Harlem Grown" à Harlem, ont révélé à l'auteur l'inadéquation de son organisation comme solution à l'injustice systémique, provoquant en lui une tristesse et une honte profondes. 

Parallèlement, il met en doute l'idée commune selon laquelle nous vivons dans une ère de scepticisme, soutenant que nous sommes aussi susceptibles de croire qu'en toute autre période historique. Il affirme qu'il y a un coût humain à cette acceptation aveugle et plaide pour un "évangile du doute". Cette pensée critique a conduit MBAs Across America à se dissoudre et à partager librement leur modèle, et l'auteur à rejeter le rôle de sauveur. Selon lui, c'est ce doute, plutôt que la foi inébranlable, qui peut éclairer nos vies, notre monde et nous offrir un véritable espoir face aux défis. Malgré le chemin parcouru, l'auteur se sent revenu à son point de départ, se sentant trompé et exploité, comparant son rôle à celui d'un faux messie.
